1. Who is Gilbert Strang? - Gilbert Strang is a mathematician and a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT).  2. What is the goal of Strang's teaching method? - The goal of Strang's teaching method is to help students think through problems, rather than simply presenting solutions. He believes that giving students time and encouraging them to think with him is crucial for their learning.  3. How does Strang use humor in his teaching? - Strang uses humor to make the learning experience more human and relatable. He believes that seeing mathematics as a natural and approachable subject can help students engage with it better.  4. How does Strang decide when to go into detail when teaching complex material? - Strang tries to think through the material and recognize the words and steps needed to convey it effectively. He also pays attention to the thinking of the class and adjusts his approach accordingly.  5. Does Strang ever encounter difficulties while demonstrating problems in real-time during lectures? - Yes, Strang sometimes gets stuck or loses the thread while working through problems in real-time. However, he sees this as an opportunity for students to see how to work through difficulties and find solutions, just as they will need to do in their own studies.

Gilbert Strand is a name brand when it comes to linear Algebra and the teaching style which provokes common sense, inspection and creativity in the audience. He bridges the theory very well with the application (for those in the engineering field) and makes the idea so simple and feasible to apply as was the case with video compression lecture and the single value decomposition. Sometimes, though, I wished he had an entire chapter in the course devoted to a variety of applications, at least for those specially various students who take the course for nagging urgent industry needs. Prof. Strand will remain a legend inspiration to promoting linear algebra as the most outstanding field in modern mathematics. He was perhaps the first one to note that linear algebra was underrated in comparison to calculus or even in the calculus linearization techniques. Much thanks and admiration to the living legend!

From the syllabus, "For further study, there are suggested readings in Professor Strang’s textbook (both the 4th and 5th editions): Strang, Gilbert. Introduction to Linear Algebra. 4th ed. Wellesley, MA: Wellesley-Cambridge Press, February 2009. ISBN: 9780980232714 Strang, Gilbert. Introduction to Linear Algebra. 5th ed. Wellesley, MA: Wellesley-Cambridge Press, February 2016. ISBN: 9780980232776"  See the course materials at: https://ocw.mit.edu/18-06SCF11. Best wishes on your studies!

After years of using linear algebra, both in fundamental problem formulation, and in numerical computation, I can say that Prof. Strang's approach to teaching the subject is by far the most direct, comprehensible, practical, satisfying, and even beautiful pathway into the subject. In particular he makes front and center key nuggets often ignored or insufficiently emphasized, such as the column picture, the fundamental vector spaces of a matrix, the big, must-see  factorizations of a matrix, and even a most satisfying way of looking at least squares. Going through his lectures, I learned a lot of wonderful things that fell through the cracks during my education.

Expressing something really complicated in an easy and fun way is not about teaching or communication skills. It can only be achieved by an extremely deep understanding of the subject. Some might say their teachers teach badly because they don't have the passion or don't care about students. The surprising truth is that they actually don't have a deep enough understanding of those seemingly easy topics.

Thank you Gilbert Strang. I remember when I was an undergraduate in 2010 and studying linear algebra. I didn't understand anything going on, and found your videos on MIT open courseware. Not only did you get me to understand linear algebra, but your lectures sparked my interest in math. I decided to become a math major after the course. Now it is 12 years later and I am again taking a matrix theory course for my part time graduate degree and again are using your videos. Thank you again for everything you have done for us, people who never stepped foot on MIT. Your impact on the world is enormous and your contributions should be appreciated!
I wish I could make you immortal. You are a legend.

Strang is immensely passionate about his subject matter; a master of his domain — a caring, objective, and gifted communicator, never an arrogant showoff.  He intuitively knows how to pump life into seemingly dry material, shows everything by example without skipping critical steps, follows a clear and logical roadmap that leads to a strong framework for envisioning and dealing with practical applications, enables you to learn the myriad of technologies without losing sight of the interconnections and the big picture; and above all, he puts himself in the students’ shoes and patiently works through the maze of potential challenges that they might face in absorbing the material.

My favourite US mathematicians are Gil and the late, great Eli Stein from Princeton.  Lovely people and great mathematical communicators. When doing proofs Eli used to say things  like: "Morally this has to be right!"  For a small homage to Gil on SVD go here: https://gotohaggstrom.com/Singular%20Value%20Decomposition%20worked%20numerical%20examples.pdf
